questions.question: The coat was ......................... than I thought.
questions.description: We use the comparative form of the adjective before than.

questions.question: Canada is ......................... India.
questions.description: Adjectives of one or two syllables form their comparative forms by adding -er to the positive adjective.

questions.question: He is not ................................. his brother.
questions.description: When we make comparisons using the positive adjective, we use the structure as...as...

questions.question: Greenland is ......................... island in the world.
questions.description: The superlative adjective is used when we compare one thing with the group to which it belongs.

questions.question: This is ............................ film I have ever watched.
questions.description: Here we are comparing one film with all the films, and therefore a superlative adjective is used.

questions.question: I am not very hungry so I will give you the ....................... steak.
questions.description: When a group has only two members, we can use either the comparative or the superlative however, the comparative is considered more appropriate here.

questions.question: This is ........................... carpet I have seen.
She solved the puzzle ............................. than everybody else.
questions.description: Either quicker or more quickly is possible here.

questions.question: I would be ............................ if I had more chin.
questions.description: Some compound adjectives like good-looking have two possible comparatives.

questions.question: Thank you very much. That was ........................... of you.
questions.description: Most can be used with adjectives to mean 'very'. So the sentence 'That was most kind of you' means 'That was very kind of you'.

questions.question: You are .......................... your mother than your father.
